title.native: 伊藤潤二「コレクション」

description: Anime adaptation of stories from both the 11-volume Ito Junji Kessaku-shuu series and the Fragments of Horror book.
synonyms: จุนจิ อิโต้ คอลเลคชั่นสยอง

tags.name: Anthology
tags.description: A collection of separate works collated into a single release.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Ghost
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is a ghost.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Curses
tags.description: Features a character, object or area that has been cursed, usually by a malevolent supernatural force.

tags.name: Monster Girl
tags.description: Prominently features a female character who is part-monster.

tags.name: Josei
tags.description: Target demographic is adult females.

tags.name: Suicide
tags.description: The act or an instance of taking or attempting to take one's own life voluntarily and intentionally.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Circus
tags.description: Prominently features a circus.

tags.name: Filmmaking
tags.description: Centers around the art of filmmaking.

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

title.native: 伊藤潤二「コレクション」富江

alternative: Black Sheep of the Tsujii Family

node.description:
__Spouse:__ [Ishiguro Ayako (石黒亜矢子)](https://twitter.com/ishiguroayako)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/junjiitofficial)

__Introduction:__
Junji Itou is a Japanese writer, penciller, inker and mangaka, who is best known for his horror manga. Some of his notable works include [The Enigma of Amigara Fault](https://anilist.co/manga/112978/The-Enigma-of-Amigara-Fault/), [Tomie](https://anilist.co/manga/30912/Tomie/), [Uzumaki](https://anilist.co/manga/30436/Uzumaki-Spiral-into-Horror/), and [Gyo](https://anilist.co/manga/30909/Gyo/).

He was inspired from a young age by both his older sisters' drawings and the work of [Kazuo Umezu](https://anilist.co/staff/97777/Kazuo-Umezu). Itou first began writing and drawing manga as a hobby while working as a dental technician in the early 1990s. In 1987, he submitted a short story to Gekkan Halloween that won an honorable mention in the Kazuo Umezu Prize (with Umezu himself as one of the judges). This story was later serialized as Tomie.

In addition to [Kazuo Umezu](https://anilist.co/staff/97777/Kazuo-Umezu), Itou has cited [Hideshi Hino](https://anilist.co/staff/99735/Hideshi-Hino), [Shinichi Koga](https://anilist.co/staff/119971/Shinichi-Koga), [Yasutaka Tsutsui](https://anilist.co/staff/97488/Yasutaka-Tsutsui) and [H.P. Lovecraft](https://anilist.co/staff/101086/H-P-Lovecraft) as being major influences to his work. The universe Itou depicts is cruel and capricious, his characters often find themselves victims of malevolent unnatural circumstances for no discernible reason, or they are punished out of proportion for minor infractions against an unknown and incomprehensible natural order. Some of the recurring themes of Itou's work include body horror, seemingly ordinary characters who begin to act out of irrational compulsion, the breakdown of society, deep-sea organisms, and the inevitability of one's demise.

Film director Guillermo del Toro cited on his official Twitter account that Itou was originally a collaborator for the video game Silent Hills, of which both Del Toro and game designer [Hideo Kojima](https://anilist.co/staff/100732/Hideo-Kojima) were the main directors, however, a year after its announcement the project was canceled by [Konami](https://anilist.co/studio/85/Konami), the IP's owner. Itou and Del Toro would later lend their likenesses towards Kojima's next project, Death Stranding.

In 2006, Junji married Ishiguro Ayako, who is a picture book artist. As of 2013, they have two children. In 2019, Itou received an Eisner Award for his manga adaptation of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.

__Alma Mater:__ Toyo University

__[Website](https://www.yukihayashi.net/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hayayu1231)__

__Introduction:__
Yuuki Hayashi is a Japanese composer and arranger affiliated with Legendoor, who used to be a rhythmic gymnast

__Biography:__
His history in music began in university when he started creating music pieces for rhythmic gymnasts as a hobby for 5000 yen a piece. When he started getting requests from other universities for his music, his interest in music producing grew. After graduation, he was taught music for 6 months by a rhythmic gymnastics music producer, and now, he handles music for various sports. He also arranges music for dance, athletic competitions, companies, independent movies and recently, TV dramas and anime.

(Source: MyAnimeList, edited)

__[Website](http://thepinballs.org/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/PINS_official) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/thepinballs) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCE_zZ1mX8I0IvPKVaHHzbwQ)__

__Formed:__ 2006

__Introduction:__
The Pinballs, alternatively known as PINS, is a four-piece Japanese rock band from Saitama Prefecture, who are under record labels No Big Deal Records and Nippon Columbia (Dec 2017–). Their music is influenced by other Japanese rock bands, such as THEE MICHELLE GUN ELEPHANT and BLANKEY JET CITY, while also harboring roots in music brought about during the "British Invasion", from artist like The Who and The Rolling Stones.

__Members:__
- Takayuki Furukawa (古川貴之, フルカワタカユキ) – vocalist, guitarist
- Tomohiro Nakaya (中屋智裕, ナカヤトモヒロ) – guitarist
- Hirotaka Morishita(森下拓貴, モリシタヒロタカ) – bassist
- Takashi Ishihara (石原天, イシハラタカシ) – drummer

__[Website](http://thepinballs.org/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/PINS_official) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/thepinballs) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCE_zZ1mX8I0IvPKVaHHzbwQ)__
